respondant: Customs, Excise and Gold (Control) Appellate Tribunal (C.E.G.A.T.)

accussed_details.name: Ashok Soota
allegation: Misrepresentation and suppression of facts regarding import valuation
Splitting value of manuals and diskettes to evade higher duty

complaint_summary: The appellant allegedly misrepresented the valuation of imported manuals and diskettes to evade higher customs duty.
investigation_summary: The Customs Department found that the manuals and diskettes were essential components of software packages and should be assessed together. Statements from company officials supported this conclusion.
judgment_summary: The court upheld the Tribunal's decision requiring a pre-deposit of 50% of the total duty and penalty demanded, rejecting claims of undue hardship and procedural errors.
punishment: Pre-deposit of Rs. 40,16,000/- directed; penalty on President stayed subject to compliance.
Decision_or_verdict: Appeals dismissed; extended time granted for pre-deposit compliance.
legal_arguments: Appellant argued undue hardship due to cash flow issues.
Appellant claimed procedural error in Tribunal's omission to consider limitation.
Tribunal found prima facie misrepresentation in splitting valuation of manuals and diskettes.
sections: Section 35F of Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944
citations: Rajendrakumar R. Shah v. Collector of Customs [1992 (58) E.L.T. 64 (Kar.)]
U.P. Lamination v. Union of India & others [1985 (20) E.L.T. 243]
Assistant Collector of Central Excise v. Dunlop India Ltd. [1985 (19) E.L.T 22 (SC)]
Bonyaiyaon Refinery & Petro Chem Ltd. v. Collector of C. Ex.

witness_statement.S.S. Ramakrishnan: Confirmed manuals and diskettes are essential components sold as a single set.
witness_statement.N. Mohan: Stated manuals are integral to software packages, similar to instruction manuals for consumer electronics.

key_issues: Whether manuals and diskettes should be assessed separately or together.
Whether the Tribunal erred in requiring pre-deposit without considering limitation.

maxims.Balance of Convenience: Consideration of hardship versus public revenue interests.

legal_terms.Undue Hardship: Significant difficulty or burden caused by compliance.

words_and_phrases.Prima Facie Case: Initial evidence sufficient to establish a fact unless rebutted.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around customs duty valuation of imported manuals and diskettes. Tribunal upheld a pre-deposit requirement, finding prima facie misrepresentation by the appellant. Appeals dismissed; procedural claims rejected.

facts.company_activity: Manufacture of mini and micro computer systems

tribunal_order.relief: Recovery of balance amount stayed subject to pre-deposit compliance

issues.primary_issue: Whether the cost of manuals should be included in the cost of diskettes or assessed separately

tribunal_findings.manuals_nature: Compulsory supply essential for marketing diskettes
tribunal_findings.trade_practice: Clubbed value of manuals and diskettes

court_findings.limitation: Not required to address at interim stage
court_findings.hardship: 50% pre-deposit does not cause undue hardship
